text_headers: Civil and human rights’ activist to discuss her journey
text: Civil and human rights’ activist to discuss her journeyNews Sports Entertainment Lifestyle Guardian Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals  GUARDIANCivil and human rights’ activist to discuss her journeyVoleer Thomas/For The GuardianResidents will have the opportunity to listen to a civil and human rights activist’s journey on her countless and courageous efforts to fulfill the mission of ensuring social justice and equality for all people.The Cultural Arts Coalition, as part of its celebration of Women’s History Month, will host “A Conversation with Dr. Gwendolyn Zoharah Simmons” at 6 p.m. Thursday at the A. Quinn Jones Center’s auditorium located at 1108 NW Seventh Ave.Simmons is a scholar and activist who has worked with numerous organizations, including the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC), the National Council of Negro Women and the American Circle of Friends.“I’ve been in awe of her since I met her years ago,” said Nkwanda Jah, director of the Cultural Arts Coalition. “She’s a very special woman. We know her but we don’t know all the work she’s done in her lifetime.”Born in 1944 in Memphis, Simmons lived through the Jim Crow era and she said growing up in those times sparked her passion to be an advocate for social change.“I was living in the Jim Crow system all of my life and I hated it,” Simmons said. “I grew up with this and I knew it was wrong. I wanted change. When I look back on it, I was responding to the situation that was present.”Jah admires her contributions through SNCC, which is where Simmons volunteered to be a part of the Freedom Summer Project in an attempt to register as many African Americans to vote as possible in Mississippi — even with the threat of the Ku Klux Klan.“We’re blessed to have her in our community,” Jah said. “She’s a fabulous woman and I’m looking forward to listening to what she’s done in her life.”The conversation will be moderated by Patricia Hilliard-Nunn, Ph.D., a senior lecturer of African American studies at the University of Florida.“It’s going to be a great opportunity to learn and ask questions and dialogue with a multidisciplinary activist who’s located right here in our community,” Hilliard-Nunn said. “Her experiences are deep and wise. She’s engaged in a variety of works not only as an activist, but as a scholar.”Simmons was a UF professor in the Department of Religion since 2000 until she retired in 2019. She was also an affiliate faculty member in both the Center for Gender, Sexualities and Women’s Studies Research and in African American Studies.Some of the countries Simmons have traveled to are Vietnam, Cambodia and Malaysia to provide humanitarian relief.In her collegiate endeavors, Simmons received her bachelor’s degree at Antioch University in 1989 and her master’s degree in 1995 from Temple University.In 2002, she received a doctorate degree from Temple University where she was part of a fellowship in Jordan and wrote a dissertation on “The Contemporary Impact of Shari’ah Law on Women’s Lives in Jordan and Palestine.”“It’s been an interesting life,” Simmons said. “I’m grateful for the travel and the experiences. I tried to share that along the way.”Hilliard-Nunn said that people need to know more about Simmons’ activism work alongside former National Council of Negro Woman President Dorothy Height and the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the iconic leader of the civil rights movement of the 1950s and 60s.“We want to know how it is like to collaborate with people all over the world to bring social change,” Hilliard-Nunn said. “When you want to understand the present, sit at the feet of your elders and get the knowledge.”Hilliard-Nunn looks forward to asking Simmons about the times we are in now, the similarities to the present and the past and her suggestions on the future.“She has an appetite to learn more and share more,” Hilliard-Nunn said. “She continues to be excited to learn about what current activists are doing in their communities.”Simmons continues to fight for social justice through her activism.She is a member of the National Women’s Liberation fighting for reproductive rights for women, a founding member of the National Council of Elders and a board member for the SNCC Legacy Project.This year will mark the 60th anniversary of SNCC being created and Simmons said she will continue to fight for the same rights the organization fought for years ago.“The problems confronted by black, poor and working-class people are still being confronted today,” Simmons said. “We still haven’t solved any of the problems that I’ve been working to solve for over 50 years.”Simmons hopes the conversation will inspire people to face and overcome the struggles of the world.“We the people have to organize for the change we want to see,” Simmons said. “Nobody is going to give it to you.
